question: Largest, covered with solid water, tallest peak is Vinson Massif in the Ellsworth Mountains, active volano is Mount Erebus, Ross Ice Shelf, Roald Amundsen (successful), Robert Scott (unuccessful), Ernest Schackleton (Endurance ship abandoned)

Second largest, Northern Africa, bound by Atlas Mountains on the north and Sahel (savannah) to the south, dominated by rocky regions, sand, salt flats, and dry river valleys (flash floods), inhabited by Berbers and Tuaregs
Chile, rain shadow of the Andes, driest hot desert, Chile defeated Peru and Bolivia over it in the War of the Pacific (1879-1883) for nitrate resources (explosives)
Botswana/Namibia/South Africa, red sand, large game reserves (meerkats, gemsbok, springbok, steenbok), mineral deposits (uranium), inhabited by San Bushmen with click language

USA, bounded by San Gabriel and San Bernadino mountain ranges along San Andreas and Garlock Faults, between Great Basin and Sonoran Desert, contains lowest/driest point of North America (Death Valley), the Joshua tree
China/Mongolia, Asia's second largest after Arabian, bounded by Atlai Mountains to the north, Silk Road trading route, Nemegt Basin, fossilized dinosaur eggs and human artifacts found here
Arabian Peninsula, name means 'Empty Quarter', most inhospitable place on Earth, Ghawar - world's largest oil field, once part of frankincense trade
Namibia/Angola, coastal desert, known for bizarre Welwitschia and medicinal Hoodia plants, thought to be the oldest desert on Earth
Northern Arizona, shared by Grand Canyon and Petrified Forest National Parks, known for its colorful/banded rock formations
Israel, triangular in shape, covers the southern half of the country
China, extremely cold and sandy, known for splitting Silk Road into branches running north and south of it, bounded by Kunlun/Pamir/Tian Shan mountain ranges
Western Australia, part of the Western Desert, ninth largest in the world
